content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE. The American Folklife Center in the Library of Congress was established in 1976 to preserve and promote cultural traditions. It has grown the Archive of Folk Culture from 500,000 to 1,500,000 multi-format items in over 20 years. The American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress has expanded its Archive of Folk Culture to 1,500,000 items, conducted cultural surveys nationwide, provided resources and services to individuals and institutions, organized educational programs, shared collections digitally, and served as a national hub for folklore and cultural studies. Congress has consistently supported American Folklife initiatives. The American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress has been supported by Congress through legislation to reauthorize it 8 times since its creation in 1976. The purpose of this Act is to permanently authorize the Center to preserve and present American Folklife. The Act aims to reauthorize and amend the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress. The American Folklife Preservation Act is being amended to appoint a Board of Trustees to oversee the Center, eliminating the Deputy Director position. Members of the Board will be appointed by the President, Senate pro tempore, and Speaker of the House. The American Folklife Preservation Act is being amended to appoint a Board of Trustees to oversee the Center, with members appointed by various officials and organizations involved in American folklife traditions and arts. The American Folklife Preservation Act is being amended to appoint a Board of Trustees to oversee the Center, with members appointed by various officials and organizations involved in American folklife traditions and arts. The President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives must consider diversity and regional balance in appointing members, with a limit on political party affiliation. The Librarian of Congress must include at least 2 members from major American folklife organizations on the Board. Members serve without pay, except for those not full-time US employees. The Board of Trustees appointed by the American Folklife Preservation Act oversees the Center, with members chosen by various officials and organizations involved in American folklife traditions. Members serve without pay, except for those who are not full-time US employees, who may be reimbursed for necessary expenses. The Board must meet at least once a fiscal year, and the Librarian appoints the Director of the Center with a specific pay range. The American Folklife Preservation Act Board oversees the Center, with members chosen by officials and organizations. Members serve without pay, except for non-full-time US employees who may be reimbursed for expenses. The Director's pay is limited to the rate of the Deputy Director. "Section 8 of the American Folklife Preservation Act is amended to authorize appropriations to the Center for each fiscal year. Additionally, there is a provision for a transition period for the Board of Trustees." The Board of Trustees appointed by the Librarian of Congress will serve 6-year terms, with initial members serving varying terms. Vacancies will be filled for the remainder of the predecessor's term, and the Presidents of the American Folklore Society and the Society for Ethnomusicology will serve concurrent terms.
